page.title: 08INTERVIEW - RYTON RESIDENT
page.content: Mr Tasylor was born in 1899 in Clara Vale. He had one sister. At the age of 14 he started work in Clara Vale mine as an apprentice blacksmith with a view to learning how to shoe horses. He worked twelve hours a day, from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. His wage was 6/- (30p) a week. When he was older he started working down the mine looking after the pit ponies which at that time were very important to Britain's mining industry. In 1913 there were about 71,000 pit ponies working in coal mines in Britain and Mr Taylor was in charge of 700 in 16 different pits in this area. At that time 1,000 tons of coal came out of the mine a day and there was an equal amount of water pumped out. When Mt Taylor has time to go on holiday he went by bus to Newbiggin or Brampton.
